question_answer.question: I'm trying to use the data cloning functionality on our F5 load balancer to duplicate data to our Cribl workers. However, the cloned syslog data from the F5 is not being seen by the Cribl worker. What could be the problem?
question_answer.answer: There could be several reasons why the cloned syslog data from the F5 is not being seen by the Cribl worker. It could be that the data is not being sent in the correct format, or there could be a Linux configuration that you're missing. You can verify if the data is coming in by using tcpdump to view the packets. Also, ensure that the local firewall on the server is turned off and that there are no iptables rules dropping the traffic.
question_answer.follow_up_question_1: I've verified that the data is coming in and that the local firewall is turned off. Could the issue be with the format in which the F5 is sending the data?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: Yes, it's possible that the F5 could be sending data in a format that the Cribl worker is not able to recognize. You might need to check with an F5 engineer to ensure that the data is being sent in a format that the Cribl worker can process.
question_answer.follow_up_question_2: I see. And what about the Linux configuration? Could there be something I'm missing there?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: Yes, there could be a Linux configuration that you're missing. For instance, you need to ensure that 'net.ipv4.all.rp_filter' is not present in sysctl. If it is, it could be preventing the Cribl worker from picking up the data.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: What if I've checked all these things and the Cribl worker still isn't picking up the data?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: If you've checked all these things and the Cribl worker still isn't picking up the data, it might be due to some other issue. It's recommended to reach out to the Cribl support team with the details of your issue for further assistance.

reference:
url,title,text_chunks https://community.cribl.io/discussion/784/cribl-edge-on-windows-how-to-handle-proxy,Cribl Edge on Windows - How to handle proxy? — Curious + Community,"I deployed Cribl on some Windows Servers. They are routing events to an on-premise Cribl Stream instance. Everything was working fine, until collection just stopped. It appears that the Edge agents aren't connecting to ""https://cdn.cribl.io/telemetry"". These servers are behind a web proxy. The proxy settings are applied properly in Windows. If I pull up a browser on the server, and surf to https://cdn.cribl.io/telemetry, I get the expected output --- “cribl /// living the stream!” I have tried: I have manually restarted the services and the Edge agent itself multiple times. Nothing has worked. What is the proper combination of settings in Windows and Cribl Edge to force the agent to use the proxy to phone home? Try this PowerShell please: Please change your proxy URLs to the correct values. This will set the environment variables on the Cribl Edge service. Try this PowerShell please: Please change your proxy URLs to the correct values. This will set the environment variables on the Cribl Edge service. This worked properly, and it DOES persist across reboots. Problem solved. Thank you Brendan! Excellent! I don't know about persisting through upgrades, so let us know if/when you do that what happens. Whoopsie…follow-up…. Two things: (1) The Powershell changes do NOT PERSIST across upgrades. After the bump from 4.4.0 to 4.4.3, I had to run them again. The output of ""Get-ItemProperty HKLM:SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Cribl -Name Environment"" was blank. Re-running the Powershell restored them. (2) Separate Issue: BEFORE the upgrade, the Powershell environment variables worked…until they didn't. Everything was still set properly, as configured by the previous commands. However, the Edge agents started failing Telemetry checks again at some point, despite the fact that the Environment variables were set properly at the time. Everything flat-lined except the regular system stats/processes/etc. POST-upgrade, even after applying the environment variables and restarting the Cribl agents (both from the Leader node and the local Windows service), there is still no event flow. Do subsequent telemetry attempts fail to use the proxy? Is there a way to FORCE the Edge clients to try and reconnect again? A good old-fashioned kick? I'm not sure what's going on in the background. © Cribl 2023 | Legal | Code of Conduct"

Distant reference chunk: url,title,text_chunks https://community.cribl.io/discussion/777/data-cloned-on-f5-and-sent-to-cribl-workers,Data cloned on F5 and sent to Cribl workers — Curious + Community,"Posting this to get community feedback and track our progress in case anyone encounters this issue in the future. We are attempting to use the data cloning functionality on our F5 load balancer to duplicate data to our Cribl workers. We want to do this so that we can route, filter, and reduce production data in Cribl without impacting production operations. When the time comes, Cribl will be ready for the cutover without much impact at all, hopefully. Right now, the F5 is sending data to our syslog servers, which then send to Splunk. The end goal is to replace syslog with Cribl, but we want to be able to see all the data in Cribl before then so that we can operate on it. We are successfully cloning data that comes from Splunk UFs and HFs, but the cloned syslog data from the F5 is not being seen by the Cribl worker. The specific problem is this: The data is making it to the to the correct interface and port on the worker, but is not being picked up by Cribl for whatever reason. I have verified that data is coming in by using tcpdump to view the packets. We have turned off the local firewall on the server. There are no iptables rules dropping the traffic. I have verified ""net.ipv4.all.rp_filter"" is not present in sysctl. I'm not an F5 engineer, so I am mostly looking for feedback from that standpoint. Could the F5 be sending data in the wrong format, if that makes sense? My logic is that if the data is hitting the correct interface/port on the worker, then Cribl should be picking it up, but maybe that logic is flawed. Maybe there is a Linux configuration I am missing. Funny thing is, we can see the UDP port monitoring traffic that the F5 sends to the worker, but not the data that it is cloning and sending. © Cribl 2023 | Legal | Code of Conduct"

question_answer.question: What is Cribl University and what does it offer?
question_answer.answer: Cribl University offers a range of courses designed to introduce, educate, and validate a student's ability to effectively use Cribl’s Stream solution. It provides in-depth, practically-oriented courses to help individuals become Stream experts within their organization. It also offers a Cribl Certified Service Consultant (CCSC) curriculum to enhance partner’s deployment readiness for Cribl solutions.
question_answer.follow_up_question_1: What are some of the topics covered in the courses?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: The courses cover a range of topics including deployment options, general Stream components, basic configurations, Pipeline configuration and operation, and best practices. They also offer deep dives on common roadblocks and strategic topics to help fill in the gaps.
question_answer.follow_up_question_2: Are there any prerequisites to enroll in these courses?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: The courses are designed to cater to different levels of expertise, from beginners to advanced users. So, while some courses might require a basic understanding of observability and the Cribl solution suite, others are more advanced and may require prior knowledge or experience.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: Are there any certification programs available?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: Yes, Cribl University offers the Cribl Certified Service Consultant (CCSC) curriculum. This program is designed to develop and enhance a partner’s deployment readiness for Cribl solutions.

question_answer.question: What is the Cribl Community and what can I find there?
question_answer.answer: The Cribl Community is a platform where users can engage with each other and with the Cribl team. It's a place to ask questions, share knowledge, and learn from others. The 'Packs' category, for example, is a place where users can share and find packs, which are collections of configurations that can be imported into Cribl Stream to quickly set up specific use cases.
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: Packs in the Cribl Community are collections of configurations that can be imported into Cribl Stream. They're designed to help users quickly set up specific use cases without having to configure everything from scratch. Users can share their own packs and use packs shared by others.
question_answer.follow_up_question_2: How can I contribute to the Cribl Community?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: You can contribute to the Cribl Community by asking questions, sharing your knowledge, and creating and sharing packs. By actively participating, you can help others and learn from them at the same time.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: Is there a code of conduct in the Cribl Community?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: Yes, the Cribl Community has a Code of Conduct that all members are expected to follow. This helps ensure that the community remains a respectful and productive environment for all its members.

question_answer.question: What value would Stream provide to a customer who already has a well-maintained and functioning logstash for routing/transforming data?
question_answer.answer: Stream can provide several benefits over a well-maintained and functioning logstash. These include the ability to build configurations manually versus using an out of the box solution with Cribl, reduction use cases such as Suppress, Sample, Drop, and log to metrics, the ability to replay historical data, enrich with Lookup, and reshape for Elastic SIEM.
question_answer.follow_up_question_1: Can you elaborate on the reduction use cases?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: Sure, reduction use cases refer to the ability to manage and control the volume of data. This can be done through suppression, sampling, dropping, or converting log data to metrics. These features can help in reducing the cost and improving the efficiency of data processing.
question_answer.follow_up_question_2: What does 'reshape for Elastic SIEM' mean?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: Reshaping for Elastic SIEM means transforming the data in a way that it can be easily ingested and used by Elastic's Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system. This can help in improving the security analytics and threat detection capabilities of the system.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: How does Stream compare to logstash in terms of efficiency?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: According to a blog post on Cribl's website, Cribl LogStream is 7x more efficient than logstash and fluentd. This means it can process the same amount of data using less resources, which can lead to significant cost savings.

Overall, I would go after these use cases: Build configurations manually (logstash) vs out of the box solution (Cribl) Reduction use cases (Suppress, Sample, Drop, log to metrics) Replay historical data Enrich with Lookup Reshape for Elastic SIEM https://www.elastic.co/blog/elastic-cribl-migrate-siem https://cribl.io/customers/sally-beauty/ https://cribl.io/blog/cribl-logstream-7x-more-efficient-than-logstash-and-fluentd/ Overall, I would go after these use cases: Build configurations manually (logstash) vs out of the box solution (Cribl) Reduction use cases (Suppress, Sample, Drop, log to metrics) Replay historical data Enrich with Lookup Reshape for Elastic SIEM https://www.elastic.co/blog/elastic-cribl-migrate-siem https://cribl.io/customers/sally-beauty/ https://cribl.io/blog/cribl-logstream-7x-more-efficient-than-logstash-and-fluentd/ © Cribl 2023 | Legal | Code of Conduct"

question_answer.question: What kind of support does Cribl offer if I run into issues?
question_answer.answer: Cribl offers multiple ways to get support. You can check their Known Issues page for recommended resolutions or workarounds. For in-depth discussions or to troubleshoot technical issues, you can create a support case. You can also contact Cribl Support via email or through the Support Portal. Additionally, Cribl’s Community Slack and Cribl Curious are platforms where you can get your questions answered by a wide range of Cribl insiders and expert peer users.
question_answer.follow_up_question_1: What is the advantage of creating a support case?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: Creating a support case allows for better tracking and exchange of information. It's particularly useful for in-depth discussions or troubleshooting technical issues. The Support Portal also allows for encrypted transfer of large files and maintains a history of your support cases for easy review.
question_answer.follow_up_question_2: What is Cribl Curious and how can it help me?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: Cribl Curious is a threaded community Q&A site. It's monitored by Cribl's support staff and other teams. It's best for issues that aren’t critical or urgent. It allows you to get answers from a wide range of Cribl insiders and expert peer users who enjoy sharing their knowledge of the product.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: How can I access the Cribl Support Portal?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: The Cribl Support Portal is available to licensed customers. It uses single sign-on (SSO) through an integration with Cribl.Cloud accounts. As part of Support Portal signup, you’ll receive an invitation to create a Cribl.Cloud account, if you don’t already have one.

Distant reference chunk: url,title,text_chunks https://docs.cribl.io/stream/support-contact/#support-portal,Working with Cribl Support | Cribl Docs,"If you run into issues with CriblÂ Stream, please first check our Known Issues page for recommended resolutions or workarounds. For questions not addressed there, this page outlines how to engage with the Cribl Support staff to resolve problems as quickly as possible. You can contact Cribl Support in multiple ways, outlined below: The best method depends on your reason for contacting Support. For quick, question-and-answer discussions, Community Slack or CriblÂ Curious might be sufficient. For in-depth discussions, or to troubleshoot technical issues, createÂ a support case for better tracking and exchange of information. You have two options for opening a support case: via email or via the Support Portal (access here, details below). If you exchange diags or other files with us, note that all file-transfer methods except for email are encrypted. Email communication imposes a total message-size limit of 25 MB (after MIME-encoding attachments). The Support Portal allows file attachments of up to 100 MB each. The simplest way to engage with Support is to email support@cribl.io, with the information outlined below. This will automatically open a case for us to track, and will send you an auto-confirmation email that includes your case number. A Support engineer will then contact you to begin troubleshooting. Within CriblÂ Stream’s UI, you can click the top-right Support button and, in the resulting Support drawer, select the GetÂ Help upper tab. Then click EmailÂ support. This will create a new email to us in your email client. Our Support staff monitors Cribl’s Community Slack for any issues customers are experiencing: https://criblâcommunity.slack.com/. If you are not already registered for our Community Slack, please register at https://cribl.io/community/ to get started. Slack might not get you the same timely response as an email, but it’s a great way to get questions about CriblÂ Stream answered by a wide range of Cribl insiders, and expert peer users, who enjoy sharing their knowledge of the product. Check out individual channels dedicated to feature requests, docs, and other concerns. Our Enterprise customers have their own private channels where they can communicate directly with their Cribl account team. CriblÂ Curious is a threaded community Q&A site. OurÂ support staff monitors it, as do other Cribl teams. AsÂ with CommunityÂ Slack, itâs best for issues that aren’t critical or urgent. The Cribl Support Portal is available to our licensed customers. It facilitates encrypted transfer of large files, and maintains support cases’ history so that you can easily review them. The Support Portal uses single sign-on (SSO) through an integration with Cribl.Cloud accounts. So as part of SupportÂ Portal signup, you’ll receive an invitation to create a Cribl.Cloud account, if you don’t already have one. YouÂ have no obligation to use your Cribl.Cloud Organization for purposes other than SSO, if it doesn’t meet your needs. For details about navigating Cribl.Cloud, see the Cribl.Cloud. The Support Portal enables two types of users: Standard and Admin. You can have up to four user logins per customer account, one of which can be (but is not required to be) an Admin user. Standard users can: Admin users can do all of the above, plus: You’ll need to receive a Cribl.Cloud invitation from Cribl or your Support Portal Admin, and follow the directions in the email to sign up. Both scenarios are summarized below. But first, a word from our sponsor, us: This video walks you through signing up for the SupportÂ Portal, and then submitting cases with enough detail for CriblÂ Support to rapidly help you. Accessing the Cribl Support Portal To access the Cribl Support Portal if you already have a Cribl.Cloud account: To access the Cribl Support Portal without an existing Cribl.Cloud account: To access the Cribl Support Portal as an Admin user: Contact Cribl Support to request Admin access. If your customer account already has an Admin user, the current Admin must also contact Cribl, requesting to transfer the account’s sole Admin user role to you.The request from the current Portal Admin must originate from the email address we have on file for that Admin user. We can tell you who the current Admin is, if you do not know. If you have an existing Cribl.Cloud account, then Cribl Support will promote your account to Admin.If you do not yet have a Cribl.Cloud account, CriblÂ Support will email you a SupportÂ Portal signup invitation. Follow the link in the email to accept the invitation, using the same email address at which you received the invitation. All support cases must be submitted by an individual account (not a shared or group account). However, there are broader notification options. When you create a new case, note the two fields for Related Teammates. Each name entered here must be an existing Contact on your customer account. If you want to enter one of your own organizationâs group email addresses, contact Cribl Support to create a contact entry for that address. When contacting Cribl Support via any means, please provide as many of the following details as you can â the more, the better: Providing us diags from your environment will speed up the time to resolution. For instructions on how to pull a diag file, see DiagnosingÂ Issues. With CriblÂ Stream (LogStream) 2.4.1 or later, and Cribl Edge, the diag is uploaded from the browser, rather than from the Node. This means that your WorkerÂ Nodes do not need internet access. With LogStream 2.4.0 or earlier, youâll need to transfer the diags from your Worker Nodes. Diag bundles for Leader Nodes do not include diag bundles for any WorkerÂ Nodes. If you would like to upload your diag file via the GUI or CLI, you’ll need outbound internet access to the upload URL (https://diag-upload.cribl.io), plus a valid support case number (provided in your case confirmation email). If your organization does not permit outbound access to https://diag-upload.cribl.io to upload from within CriblÂ Stream, you can also submit diags directly via the Support Portal (login required). If none of these options work with your organization’s policies, please work directly with your Support engineer to find a solution."

question_answer.question: What is Cribl Stream and how does it benefit a user?
question_answer.answer: Cribl Stream is an observability pipeline that offers flexibility in collecting, reducing, enriching, normalizing, and routing data from any source to any destination within your existing data infrastructure. It's vendor-agnostic, meaning it can work with any data source or destination. This flexibility can lead to more comprehensive and effective data analysis and insights.
question_answer.follow_up_question_1: What does it mean for Cribl Stream to be 'vendor-agnostic'?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: Being 'vendor-agnostic' means that Cribl Stream is not tied to any specific vendor or technology. It can collect and route data from any source to any destination, regardless of the technology or vendor involved. This gives users the freedom to choose the best tools for their needs without worrying about compatibility issues.
question_answer.follow_up_question_2: What other products does Cribl offer?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: In addition to Stream, Cribl offers Cribl Edge, an intelligent, highly scalable edge-based data collection system for logs, metrics, and application data. They also offer Cribl Search, which allows users to search data in place without having to collect/store first. Lastly, they have the Cribl.Cloud platform, which provides a fast and easy way to realize the value of an observability ecosystem without the hassle of running infrastructure.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: How does Cribl Search turn the traditional search process on its head?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: Traditional search processes often involve collecting and storing data before it can be searched. Cribl Search, on the other hand, allows users to search data in place, without the need for prior collection or storage. This can save significant time and resources, especially when dealing with large volumes of data.

reference:
url,title,text_chunks https://community.cribl.io/discussion/782/what-value-would-stream-provide-to-someone-who-has-logstash-for-routing-transforming,What value would Stream provide to someone who has logstash for routing/transforming? — Curious + Community,"So, this question has been bothering me for quite some time now. While I am a big fan of Cribl and I really enjoy working with their products and showing/explaining them to others I still wonder every now and then what value Stream would provide to a customer, who already has a well-maintained and functioning logstash for routing/transforming data. If I think about it the following points come to my mind, but if someone here has more/different reasons I would be glad to hear them! Overall, I would go after these use cases: Build configurations manually (logstash) vs out of the box solution (Cribl) Reduction use cases (Suppress, Sample, Drop, log to metrics) Replay historical data Enrich with Lookup Reshape for Elastic SIEM https://www.elastic.co/blog/elastic-cribl-migrate-siem https://cribl.io/customers/sally-beauty/ https://cribl.io/blog/cribl-logstream-7x-more-efficient-than-logstash-and-fluentd/ Overall, I would go after these use cases: Build configurations manually (logstash) vs out of the box solution (Cribl) Reduction use cases (Suppress, Sample, Drop, log to metrics) Replay historical data Enrich with Lookup Reshape for Elastic SIEM https://www.elastic.co/blog/elastic-cribl-migrate-siem https://cribl.io/customers/sally-beauty/ https://cribl.io/blog/cribl-logstream-7x-more-efficient-than-logstash-and-fluentd/ © Cribl 2023 | Legal | Code of Conduct"

question_answer.question: What is Cribl Stream and how does it benefit my business?
question_answer.answer: Cribl Stream is a vendor-agnostic observability pipeline that gives you the flexibility to collect, reduce, enrich, normalize, and route data from any source to any destination within your existing data infrastructure. This flexibility can help you gain more insights from your data and make better business decisions.
question_answer.follow_up_question_1: What other products does Cribl offer?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: In addition to Cribl Stream, Cribl offers Cribl Edge, an intelligent, highly scalable edge-based data collection system for logs, metrics, and application data. They also offer Cribl Search, which allows users to search data in place without having to collect/store first, and AppScope for visibility into application behavior, metrics and events.
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: The Cribl.Cloud platform is a cloud-based solution that gets you up and running fast without the hassle of running infrastructure. It's the fastest and easiest way to realize the value of an observability ecosystem.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: How can I try out Cribl's products?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: You can experience a full version of Cribl Stream and Cribl Edge in the cloud by launching a Cribl Sandbox. You can also download Cribl’s suite of products for free to get started.

question_answer.question: What is the Cribl Community?
question_answer.answer: The Cribl Community is a platform where users can engage in general discussions, connect with monthly community user group meetings, and stay up to date on all things Cribl and observability. It's a place to learn, share, and connect with others who are interested in Cribl's products and services.
question_answer.follow_up_question_1: What kind of discussions can I expect in the Cribl Community?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: The discussions in the Cribl Community can range from general topics about Cribl's products and services, to specific use cases and experiences shared by community members. It's a great place to learn from others' experiences and get inspired.
question_answer.follow_up_question_2: Are there any guidelines or code of conduct for participating in the Cribl Community?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: Yes, Cribl has a Code of Conduct that all community members are expected to adhere to. This ensures that the community remains a respectful and inclusive space for everyone.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: How can I join the Cribl Community?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: You can join the Cribl Community by visiting their website and signing up. Once you're a member, you can participate in discussions, join user group meetings, and stay updated on the latest news and updates from Cribl.

question_answer.question: What is Cribl Search and how does it differ from traditional search processes?
question_answer.answer: Cribl Search is a tool that turns the traditional search process on its head by allowing users to search data in place without having to collect or store it first. This can lead to significant cost savings and efficiency improvements.
question_answer.follow_up_question_1: How does searching data in place work and what are its advantages?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_1: Searching data in place means that instead of collecting and storing data before you can search it, you can search the data directly where it resides. This can significantly reduce storage costs and the time it takes to get results. It also means you can search across all your data, not just the data you've chosen to collect and store.
question_answer.follow_up_question_2: What is Cribl.Cloud and how does it help in realizing the value of an observability ecosystem?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_2: Cribl.Cloud is a platform that gets you up and running fast without the hassle of running infrastructure. It's the fastest and easiest way to realize the value of an observability ecosystem as it allows you to quickly deploy and scale Cribl's solutions without having to manage the underlying infrastructure.
question_answer.follow_up_question_3: What is the Cribl community and how can I engage with it?
question_answer.follow_up_answer_3: The Cribl community is a space where users of Cribl's products can connect, share experiences, and learn from each other. You can engage with the community through their monthly user group meetings and through their general discussions forum. It's a great way to get insights from other users and stay up to date with the latest developments.
